articles.title: Light-printed electrodes turn skin and clothing into sensors
articles.summary: Researchers in Sweden have unveiled a way to create high-performance electronic electrodes using nothing more than visible light and specially designed water-soluble monomers. This gentle, chemical-free approach lets conductive plastics form directly on surfaces ranging from glass to textiles to living skin, enabling surprisingly versatile electronic and medical applications.
articles.content:
Researchers at Linköping and Lund universities in Sweden have demonstrated that visible light can be used to form electrodes from conductive plastics without the need for dangerous chemicals. Their results show that these electrodes can be produced on a wide variety of surfaces, creating opportunities for new types of electronics and medical sensing technologies.

"I think this is something of a breakthrough. It's another way of creating electronics that is simpler and doesn't require any expensive equipment," says Xenofon Strakosas, assistant professor at the Laboratory of Organic Electronics, LOE, at Linköping University.

Conductive Plastics and Their Role in Electronics

Scientists at LOE focus on conductive plastics, also known as conjugated polymers, to advance fields such as renewable energy and medical technology. These materials combine the functional qualities of metals and semiconductors with the bendability and light weight of plastics.

Polymers are made up of long chains of hydrocarbons. Each unit in the chain is called a monomer, and linking these monomers creates a polymer. The formation process, known as polymerization, is often carried out with strong or toxic chemicals, which restricts both scaling and the safe use of the materials in areas such as medicine.

Visible Light Enables a Chemical-Free Polymerization Process

Researchers at Campus Norrköping, collaborating with colleagues in Lund and New Jersey, have developed a technique that allows polymerization to occur using only visible light. This advance relies on specially engineered water-soluble monomers. Because the monomers activate under visible light, creating electrodes no longer requires toxic chemicals, harmful UV light or additional processing steps.

"It's possible to create electrodes on different surfaces such as glass, textiles and even skin. This opens up a much wider range of applications," says Xenofon Strakosas.

Patterning Electrodes Directly With Light

In practical use, a solution containing the monomers is placed on a surface. By directing a laser or another light source across the material, researchers can form electrodes in detailed patterns right where they are needed. Any portion of the solution that does not undergo polymerization can be washed away, leaving the finished electrodes behind.

"The electrical properties of the material are at the very forefront. As the material can transport both electrons and ions, it can communicate with the body in a natural way, and its gentle chemistry ensures that tissue tolerates it -- a combination that is crucial for medical applications," says Tobias Abrahamsson, researcher at LOE and lead author of the article published in the scientific journal Angewandte Chemie.

Improved Brain Signal Recording and Future Applications

The team evaluated their approach by photo-patterning electrodes directly onto the skin of anaesthetised mice. These tests revealed significantly better recordings of low-frequency brain activity compared to conventional metal EEG electrodes.

"As the method works on many different surfaces, you can also imagine sensors built into garments. In addition, the method could be used for large-scale manufacture of organic electronics circuits, without dangerous solvents," says Tobias Abrahamsson.

articles.personality_title: Swedish researchers create safe, light-made electrodes for skin and clothes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists often use strong chemicals to make electronic materials called conductive plastics. These plastics can bend and stretch, unlike metals, but making them safely and cheaply has been hard.

**What happened** – Researchers in Sweden found a way to make electrodes by shining visible light on special water-based chemicals called monomers. This process forms conductive plastics directly on surfaces like glass, fabric, or even skin without harmful chemicals or ultraviolet light. They tested this by printing electrodes on mice skin and got better brain signal readings than usual metal electrodes.

**Impact** – This new method is simpler, safer, and works on many surfaces. It could lead to better medical sensors that stick to skin or smart clothes that monitor health. Also, it can help make flexible electronics on a large scale without dangerous chemicals.

**What's next step** – Scientists will explore using this technique in real medical devices and wearable technology. They may also develop ways to produce circuits for electronics more easily and safely.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Swedish researchers developed a safe, light-based method to print flexible electronic electrodes on skin and fabrics, opening new paths for medical and wearable devices.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des chercheurs suédois créent des électrodes sûres imprimées à la lumière pour la peau et les vêtements
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques utilisent souvent des produits chimiques puissants pour fabriquer des matériaux électroniques appelés plastiques conducteurs. Ces plastiques peuvent se plier et s’étirer, contrairement aux métaux, mais leur fabrication sûre et économique est difficile.

Ce procédé forme des plastiques conducteurs directement sur des surfaces comme le verre, le tissu ou même la peau, sans produits chimiques nocifs ni lumière ultraviolette. **Impact** – Cette nouvelle méthode est plus simple, plus sûre et fonctionne sur de nombreuses surfaces. Elle pourrait permettre de meilleurs capteurs médicaux adhérant à la peau ou des vêtements intelligents qui surveillent la santé. Elle peut aussi aider à fabriquer des électroniques flexibles à grande échelle sans produits chimiques dangereux.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont explorer l’usage de cette technique dans des dispositifs médicaux réels et des technologies portables. Ils pourraient aussi développer des moyens de produire plus facilement et sûrement des circuits électroniques.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des chercheurs suédois ont mis au point une méthode sûre, basée sur la lumière, pour imprimer des électrodes électroniques flexibles sur la peau et les tissus, ouvrant de nouvelles voies pour les dispositifs médicaux et portables.

articles.title: Hidden dimensions could explain where mass comes from
articles.summary: A new theory proposes that the universe’s fundamental forces and particle properties may arise from the geometry of hidden extra dimensions. These dimensions could twist and evolve over time, forming stable structures that generate mass and symmetry breaking on their own. The approach may even explain cosmic expansion and predict a new particle. It hints at a universe built entirely from geometry.
articles.content:
The geometry of space itself may play a far more central role in physics than previously thought. Instead of serving only as the backdrop where forces act, spacetime may be responsible for the forces and particles that make up the universe.

New theoretical work suggests that the fundamental behavior of nature could arise directly from the structure of spacetime, pointing to geometry as the common origin of physical interactions.

Hidden Dimensions and Seven-Dimensional Geometry

In a paper published in Nuclear Physics B, physicist Richard Pincak and collaborators examine whether the properties of matter and forces can emerge from the geometry of unseen dimensions beyond everyday space.

Their research proposes that the universe includes additional dimensions that are not directly observable. These dimensions may be compact and folded into complex seven-dimensional shapes called G 2 -manifolds. Until now, such geometric structures were typically treated as fixed and unchanging. The new study instead explores what happens when these shapes are allowed to evolve over time through a mathematical process known as the G 2 -Ricci flow, which gradually alters their internal geometry.

Twisting Geometry and Stable Structures

"As in organic systems, such as the twisting of DNA or the handedness of amino acids, these extra-dimensional structures can possess torsion, a kind of intrinsic twist," explains Pincak. This torsion introduces a built-in rotation within the geometry itself.

When the researchers modeled how these twisted shapes change over time, they found that the geometry can naturally settle into stable patterns called solitons. "When we let them evolve in time, we find that they can settle into stable configurations called solitons. These solitons could provide a purely geometric explanation of phenomena such as spontaneous symmetry breaking."

Rethinking the Origin of Mass

In the Standard Model of particle physics, mass arises through interactions with the Higgs field, which gives weight to particles such as the W and Z bosons. The new theory suggests a different possibility. Instead of relying on a separate field, mass may result from torsion within extra-dimensional geometry itself.

"In our picture," Pincak says, "matter emerges from the resistance of geometry itself, not from an external field." In this view, mass reflects how spacetime responds to its own internal structure rather than the influence of an added physical ingredient.

Cosmic Expansion and a Possible New Particle

The researchers also connect geometric torsion to the curvature of spacetime on large scales. This relationship could help explain the positive cosmological constant associated with the accelerating expansion of the universe.

Beyond these cosmological implications, the team speculates about the existence of a previously unknown particle linked to torsion, which they call the "Torstone." If real, it could potentially be detected in future experiments.

Extending Einstein's Geometric Vision

The broader ambition of the work is to push Einstein's idea further. If gravity arises from geometry, the authors ask whether all fundamental forces might share the same origin. As Pincak puts it, "Nature often prefers simple solutions. Perhaps the masses of the W and Z bosons come not from the famous Higgs field, but directly from the geometry of seven-dimensional space."

The article published in the journal Nuclear Physics B.

The research was supported by R3 project No.09I03-03-V04-00356.
articles.reasoning: The article presents a significant theoretical breakthrough in fundamental physics proposing that mass and fundamental forces arise from the geometry of hidden extra dimensions. This new approach could reshape our understanding of the universe, potentially explaining cosmic expansion and predicting new particles, thus having broad scientific and societal implications.

articles.title: Researchers find how plants survive without sunlight or sex
articles.summary: The study reveals how Balanophora plants function despite abandoning photosynthesis and, in some species, sexual reproduction. Their plastid genomes shrank dramatically in a shared ancestor, yet the plastids remain vital. Asexual reproduction appears to have evolved repeatedly, helping the plants survive in isolated, humid forest habitats. The research highlights surprising resilience in these bizarre parasitic species.
articles.content:
Some plants lack both green pigments and sexual reproduction, yet these unusual traits reveal important insights into what defines plant life. A new study involving Kobe University examined species in the genus Balanophora to understand how non-green, asexual plants develop and survive.

"My long-standing aim is to rethink what it truly means to be a plant," says Kobe University botanist Kenji Suetsugu. He continues, "For many years I have been fascinated by plants that have abandoned photosynthesis, and I want to uncover the changes that occur in the process." Balanophora species represent an extreme case because they do not photosynthesize and instead draw nutrients from the roots of host plants. They remain underground for most of their lives and appear above the soil only during flowering season, and some species reproduce only through asexual means. "However, while there have been individual studies on changes in the plants' genomes, their ecology and their reproduction, we don't know how they relate to each other," explains Suetsugu.

Linking Evolution, Plastids, and Ecology in Balanophora

To address this gap, Suetsugu set out to unify three areas of research that had never been examined together for Balanophora. He aimed to clarify the relationships among species, investigate how their plastids have been altered (a part of a plant's cells which in green plants serves as the cell's "solar panels"), and determine how their reproductive strategies fit within their ecological context. Describing the difficulty of the work, he says: "These plants are rare, patchy and often restricted to steep, humid forests. But years of experience with studying Balanophora both in the lab and in field studies, as well as long-standing relationships with local naturalists made this project possible." To expand the project, he collaborated with experts at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology who specialize in highly reduced genomes.

Extreme Plastid Reduction Suggests a Shared Ancestral Shift

The study, now published in the journal New Phytologist, reports that all members of the group possess a dramatically reduced plastid genome (DNA not kept in the plant cell's nucleus but directly in the plastid). The team concluded that this reduction likely occurred in a common ancestor before the lineage split into multiple species. Suetsugu says: "It is exciting to see how far a plant can reduce its plastid genome, which at first glance looks as though the plastid is on the verge of disappearing. But looking more closely we found that many proteins are still transported to the plastid, showing that even though the plant has abandoned photosynthesis, the plastid is still a vital part of the plant's metabolism."

Repeated Evolution of Asexual Reproduction Across the Region

The researchers also determined that asexual reproduction probably emerged several times within the group. Their findings suggest that the plants may have developed the capacity to produce seeds without fertilization early on, which would have helped them colonize the chain of islands extending from mainland Japan through Okinawa to Taiwan. "Over the past decade I have studied Balanophora pollination and seed dispersal where camel crickets and cockroaches play an unexpected role, but I also noticed that asexual seed production often ensured reproduction when mates or pollinators are scarce," explains Suetsugu. In some species, this reproductive approach may have become the primary mode of producing offspring.

Understanding How Parasitic, Non-Photosynthetic Plants Persist

For Suetsugu, the work represents a major step toward understanding how plants that no longer perform photosynthesis continue to function and survive in natural environments. Suetsugu says, "For someone who has spent many hours observing these plants in dark, humid forests, seeing their story unfold at the genomic level is deeply satisfying. My next goal is to connect these results with biochemical measurements to find out what Balanophora plastids actually produce and how these products help sustain the parasitic plants' growth within the roots of their hosts."

This research was funded by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (grant 23K14256), the Human Frontier Science Program (grant RGEC29/2024), the Japan Science and Technology Agency (grants JPMJPR21D6, JPMJFR2339) and the National Science and Technology Council, Taiwan (grant 109-2311-B-845-001). It was conducted in collaboration with researchers from the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology and the University of Taipei.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding how certain parasitic plants survive without photosynthesis or sexual reproduction, revealing new insights into plant biology and evolution. This discovery has broad implications for botany and ecology, representing a meaningful advancement in biological science with potential future applications.
articles.personality_title: Scientists uncover how unusual plants live without sunlight or sex
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Most plants use sunlight to make food through photosynthesis and reproduce sexually. But some rare plants in the Balanophora group do not have green pigments and do not rely on either sunlight or sexual reproduction to survive.

**What happened** – Researchers from Kobe University and other institutions studied Balanophora plants to understand how they live and reproduce. They found these plants have very small plastid genomes—the part of the cell usually responsible for photosynthesis. Despite this, the plastids still play an important role. The team also discovered that these plants have evolved to reproduce asexually multiple times, helping them survive in humid forest areas where pollinators are scarce.

**Impact** – This research shows that plants can survive and grow without photosynthesis or sexual reproduction, which is unusual. It helps scientists better understand what makes a plant a plant and reveals how life can adapt in surprising ways. The findings also explain how these parasitic plants thrive underground by stealing nutrients from host plants.

**What's next step** – The researchers plan to study what exactly the plastids produce in these plants and how this supports their growth inside host roots. This could give deeper insight into plant metabolism and parasitic relationships.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have discovered how Balanophora plants survive without sunlight or sex by shrinking their plastid genomes and evolving asexual reproduction to thrive underground and in isolated forests.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques découvrent comment des plantes vivent sans lumière ni reproduction sexuelle
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La plupart des plantes utilisent la lumière du soleil pour fabriquer leur nourriture par photosynthèse et se reproduisent sexuellement. Mais certaines plantes rares du groupe Balanophora n’ont pas de pigments verts et ne dépendent ni de la lumière ni de la reproduction sexuelle pour survivre.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Kobe et d’autres institutions ont étudié les plantes Balanophora pour comprendre comment elles vivent et se reproduisent. Ils ont découvert que ces plantes ont des génomes plastidiens très petits – la partie de la cellule normalement responsable de la photosynthèse. Malgré cela, les plastides jouent toujours un rôle important. L’équipe a aussi trouvé que ces plantes se reproduisent de façon asexuée à plusieurs reprises, ce qui les aide à survivre dans des forêts humides où il y a peu de pollinisateurs.

**Impact** – Cette recherche montre que des plantes peuvent survivre et grandir sans photosynthèse ni reproduction sexuelle, ce qui est inhabituel. Elle aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre ce qui définit une plante et révèle comment la vie peut s’adapter de façon surprenante. Les résultats expliquent aussi comment ces plantes parasites prospèrent sous terre en volant des nutriments à leurs plantes hôtes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs veulent étudier ce que les plastides produisent exactement dans ces plantes et comment cela soutient leur croissance dans les racines des hôtes. Cela pourrait permettre de mieux comprendre le métabolisme des plantes et leurs relations parasites.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont découvert comment les plantes Balanophora survivent sans lumière ni reproduction sexuelle en réduisant leurs génomes plastidiens et en développant la reproduction asexuée pour vivre sous terre et dans des forêts isolées.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren cómo plantas extrañas viven sin luz solar ni reproducción sexual
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La mayoría de las plantas usan la luz del sol para producir alimento mediante la fotosíntesis y se reproducen sexualmente. Pero algunas plantas raras del grupo Balanophora no tienen pigmentos verdes y no dependen ni de la luz ni de la reproducción sexual para sobrevivir.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Kobe y otras instituciones estudiaron las plantas Balanophora para entender cómo viven y se reproducen. Encontraron que estas plantas tienen genomas plastidiales muy pequeños, la parte de la célula que normalmente realiza la fotosíntesis. A pesar de esto, los plastidios siguen siendo importantes. El equipo también descubrió que estas plantas han evolucionado para reproducirse asexualmente varias veces, lo que les ayuda a sobrevivir en bosques húmedos donde hay pocos polinizadores.

**Impacto** – Esta investigación muestra que las plantas pueden sobrevivir y crecer sin fotosíntesis ni reproducción sexual, algo poco común. Ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor qué define a una planta y revela cómo la vida puede adaptarse de formas sorprendentes. Los hallazgos explican cómo estas plantas parásitas prosperan bajo tierra robando nutrientes de plantas hospedadoras.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean estudiar qué producen exactamente los plastidios en estas plantas y cómo esto ayuda a su crecimiento dentro de las raíces de las plantas hospedadoras. Esto podría dar más información sobre el metabolismo vegetal y las relaciones parasitarias.

**Frase clave** – Los científicos descubrieron cómo las plantas Balanophora sobreviven sin luz ni sexo al reducir sus genomas plastidiales y desarrollar la reproducción asexual para vivir bajo tierra y en bosques aislados.

articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03935-3The Sun’s fiery surface, a tattooed tardigrade, rare red lightning and more.
articles.content:
Icy ink. This tardigrade is sporting what is perhaps the world’s tiniest ‘tattoo’. Researchers used an electron beam to etch the dots into a layer of ice coating the animal. The beam transforms the substance into a compound that sticks to the tardigrade’s skin, leaving the design visible when the rest of the ice evaporates. The method’s extremely high precision means it could have applications in biomedical engineering, the scientists who developed the technique say. They are now working on tattooing even smaller organisms, including bacteria, in the same way.

Adapted from Z. Yang et al. Nano Lett. 15, 6168–6175 (2025)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a novel scientific technique with potential applications in biomedical engineering, indicating a meaningful technological breakthrough with broad future benefits.
articles.personality_title: Scientists create tiny tattoos on microscopic animals using ice and electron beams
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have found new ways to study very small living things by marking them with tiny designs. This helps researchers learn more about these creatures and how to work with them.

**What happened** – In 2025, a team of researchers used a special tool called an electron beam to make tiny tattoos on tardigrades, which are microscopic animals. They did this by shining the beam on a thin layer of ice covering the tardigrade. The beam changed the ice into a sticky compound that stayed on the tardigrade’s skin after the ice melted, creating a clear pattern.

**Impact** – This method is very precise and can make detailed marks on very small creatures without hurting them. It could help scientists track and study tiny living things better. The researchers believe this technique could be useful in biomedical engineering, possibly helping with medical or biological research at very small scales.

**What's next step** – The scientists plan to try this tattooing method on even smaller organisms, like bacteria. If successful, it could open new ways to study and work with microscopic life in medicine and science.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Researchers have developed a new way to put tiny tattoos on microscopic animals using ice and electron beams, which could help improve biomedical research.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques créent de minuscules tatouages sur des animaux microscopiques avec de la glace et des faisceaux d’électrons
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques cherchent de nouvelles méthodes pour étudier de très petits êtres vivants en les marquant avec de minuscules dessins. Cela aide à mieux comprendre ces créatures et à travailler avec elles.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2025, une équipe de chercheurs a utilisé un outil spécial appelé faisceau d’électrons pour réaliser de petits tatouages sur des tardigrades, des animaux microscopiques. Ils ont projeté le faisceau sur une fine couche de glace qui recouvrait le tardigrade. Le faisceau a transformé la glace en un composé collant qui est resté sur la peau du tardigrade après la fonte de la glace, créant un motif clair.

**Impact** – Cette méthode est très précise et peut faire des marques détaillées sur des êtres très petits sans leur faire de mal. Elle pourrait aider les scientifiques à mieux suivre et étudier les organismes microscopiques. Les chercheurs pensent que cette technique pourrait être utile en ingénierie biomédicale, aidant la recherche médicale ou biologique à très petite échelle.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques prévoient d’essayer cette méthode de tatouage sur des organismes encore plus petits, comme les bactéries. Si cela réussit, cela pourrait ouvrir de nouvelles façons d’étudier et de travailler avec la vie microscopique en médecine et en science.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Des chercheurs ont développé une nouvelle méthode pour tatouer de minuscules animaux microscopiques avec de la glace et des faisceaux d’électrons, ce qui pourrait améliorer la recherche biomédicale.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos crean tatuajes diminutos en animales microscópicos usando hielo y haces de electrones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos están buscando nuevas formas de estudiar seres vivos muy pequeños marcándolos con diseños diminutos. Esto ayuda a entender mejor a estas criaturas y cómo trabajar con ellas.

**Qué pasó** – En 2025, un equipo de investigadores usó una herramienta especial llamada haz de electrones para crear tatuajes diminutos en tardígrados, que son animales microscópicos. Aplicaron el haz sobre una capa delgada de hielo que cubría al tardígrado. El haz transformó el hielo en un compuesto pegajoso que permaneció en la piel del tardígrado después de que el hielo se evaporó, formando un diseño visible.

**Impacto** – Este método es muy preciso y puede hacer marcas detalladas en criaturas muy pequeñas sin dañarlas. Podría ayudar a los científicos a seguir y estudiar mejor a los organismos microscópicos. Los investigadores creen que esta técnica podría ser útil en ingeniería biomédica, ayudando en la investigación médica y biológica en escalas muy pequeñas.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean probar este método de tatuajes en organismos aún más pequeños, como bacterias. Si tienen éxito, esto podría abrir nuevas formas de estudiar y trabajar con la vida microscópica en medicina y ciencia.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Investigadores han desarrollado una nueva forma de poner tatuajes diminutos en animales microscópicos usando hielo y haces de electrones, lo que podría mejorar la investigación biomédica.
